questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with fatigue, low mood and weight gain. TFTS was done. She was found to have high TSH. Which of the following is not true regarding the treatment of her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: TSH responses are gradual and should be determined two months after starting the treatment

options.label: B
options.text: Once TSH levels are stabilized, TSH levels are measured annually

options.label: C
options.text: In hypothyroid patients following graves treatment, higher doses are needed for replacement

options.label: D
options.text: Daily replacement dose is 1.6ug/kg body weight

questions.correct_answer: C. In hypothyroid patients following graves treatment, higher doses are needed for replacement
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In hypothyroid patients following graves treatment, higher doses are needed for replacement In patients with hypothyroidism after graves treatment lower doses are needed as there is an underlying autonomous function making it necessary to replace with low dose If there is no residual thyroid function, the daily replacement dose of levothyroxine is usually 1.6 μg/kg body weight (typically 100–150 μg), ideally taken at least 30 min before breakfast. In many Patients, however, lower doses suffice until residual thyroid tissue is destroyed. In patients who develop hypothyroidism after the treatment of Graves’ disease, there is often underlying autonomous function .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . TSH responses are gradual, full relief takes 3-6 months after normal TSH are restored therefore determined 2 months following initiation Option: B. After full replacement, measurement is taken at annual intervals Option: D . Daily replacement is 1.6ug/kg body weight ideally taken 30 mins before breakfast

questions.text: Which of the following is true about iodine intake in pregnant females?

options.label: A
options.text: The RDA is 20 ?g iodine per day and WHO/ATA recommends no supplemental iodine

options.label: B
options.text: The RDA is 20 ?g iodine per day and WHO/ATA recommends prenatal multivitamins containing 20 ?g iodine per day

options.label: C
options.text: The RDA is 220 ?g iodine per day and WHO/ATA recommends no supplemental iodine

options.label: D
options.text: The RDA is 220 ?g iodine per day and WHO/ATA recommends prenatal multivitamins containing 150 ?g iodine per day

questions.correct_answer: D. The RDA is 220 ?g iodine per day and WHO/ATA recommends prenatal multivitamins containing 150 ?g iodine per day
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The RDA is 220 ?g iodine per day and WHO/ATA recommends prenatal multivitamins containing 150 ?g iodine per day The RDA is 220 μg iodine per day for pregnant women and 290 μg iodine per day for breastfeeding women. Because the effects of iodine deficiency are most severe in pregnant women and their babies, the American Thyroid Association has recommended that all pregnant and breastfeeding women take a prenatal multivitamin containing 150 μg iodine per day. The World Health Organization recommends a daily iodine intake of 250 μg during pregnancy and lactation and prenatal vitamins should contain 150 μg per tablet.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, B: The RDA is 220 μg iodine per day for pregnant women. Option: C: Because the effects of iodine deficiency are most severe in pregnant women and their babies, the ATA has recommended that all pregnant and breastfeeding women take a prenatal multivitamin containing 150 μg iodine per day.

questions.text: Deficiency of iodine in children leads to mental and growth retardation which is termed as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cretinism Cretinism is characterized by mental and growth retardation and occurs when children who live in iodine-deficient regions are not treated with iodine or thyroid hormone to restore normal thyroid hormone levels during early life. These children are often born to mothers with iodine deficiency, and it is likely that maternal thyroid hormone deficiency worsens the condition. Concomitant selenium deficiency may also contribute to the neurologic manifestations of cretinism. Iodine supplementation of salt, bread, and other food substances has markedly reduced the prevalence of cretinism.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: Excess of Growth hormone in adults is called acromegaly Option: B: Excess of Growth hormone in children results in gigantism Option: D: Deficiency of iodine in adults leads to myxoedema.

questions.text: Concomitant deficiency of which element may also contribute to the neurologic manifestations of cretinism?
questions.explanation:

Selenium Concomitant selenium deficiency may also contribute to the neurologic manifestations of cretinism.

Severe chronic zinc deficiency has been described as a cause of hypogonadism and dwarfism. Option: C: Copper-deficiency anaemia (refractory to therapeutic iron). Menkes kinky hair syndrome is an X-linked metabolic disturbance of copper metabolism characterized by mental retardation, hypocupremia, and decreased circulating ceruloplasmin. Option: D : Anemic manifestation.

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the Wolff-Chaikoff effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Excess iodide transiently stimulates thyroid iodide organification

options.label: B
options.text: Excess iodide transiently inhibits thyroid iodide organification

options.label: C
options.text: Deficiency of iodine transiently stimulates thyroid iodide organification

options.label: D
options.text: Deficiency of iodine transiently inhibits thyroid iodide organification

questions.correct_answer: B. Excess iodide transiently inhibits thyroid iodide organification
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Excess iodide transiently inhibits thyroid iodide organification Excess iodide transiently inhibits thyroid iodide organification, a phenomenon known as the Wolff-Chaikoff effect. In individuals with a normal thyroid, the gland escapes from this inhibitory effect and iodide organification resumes; the suppressive action of high iodide may persist, however, in patients with underlying autoimmune thyroid disease. Iodine deficiency increases thyroid blood flow and upregulates the nis, stimulating more efficient iodine uptake

questions.text: Hyperthyroidism in pregnancy is usually caused by Graves' disease and occurs in 1 to 4 of every 1,000 pregnancies in the United States. Which of the following is FALSE about Thyroid function tests in pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: TSH levels increase during the first trimester and then fall as gestation progresses

options.label: B
options.text: Total T4 and T3 levels are about 1.5× higher throughout pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: The free T4 progressively decreases so that third-trimester values in healthy pregnancies are often below the nonpregnant cutoff

options.label: D
options.text: Normative values for most thyroid function tests differ during pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: A. TSH levels increase during the first trimester and then fall as gestation progresses
questions.explanation:
Solution:

TSH levels increase during the first trimester and then fall as gestation progresses TSH levels decrease during the first trimester and then rise as gestation progresses.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: B, C. Total T4 and T3 levels are about 1.5× higher throughout pregnancy but the free T4 progressively decreases so that third-trimester values in healthy pregnancies are often below the nonpregnant lower reference cutoff. Option: D. Normative values for most thyroid function tests differ during pregnancy and, if available, trimester-specific reference ranges should be used when diagnosing thyroid dysfunction during pregnancy.

questions.text: Congenital hypothyroidism occurs when the thyroid gland fails to develop or function properly. In 80 to 85 per cent of cases, the thyroid gland is absent, severely reduced in size (hypoplastic), or abnormally located. These cases are classified as thyroid dysgenesis. Congenital hypothyroidism usually doesn't present with?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Microglossia Macro NOT Microglossia is present. Neonatal hypothyroidism presents a few cases that are now diagnosed based on clinical features, which can include prolonged jaundice, feeding problems, hypotonia, enlarged tongue, delayed bone maturation, and umbilical hernia . Importantly, permanent neurologic damage results if treatment is delayed. Typical features of adult hypothyroidism may also be present. Other congenital malformations, especially cardiac, are four times more common in congenital

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, B, D: Features of neonatal hypothyroidism.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about Antibodies to TPO and thyroglobulin (Tg)?

options.label: A
options.text: TPO antibodies fix complement, and complement membrane-attack complexes are present in the thyroid in autoimmune hypothyroidism

options.label: B
options.text: Antibodies to TPO and thyroglobulin (Tg) are clinically useful markers of thyroid autoimmunity

options.label: C
options.text: Transplacental passage of Tg or TPO antibodies induce neonatal hypothyroidism

options.label: D
options.text: Its pathogenic effect is restricted to a secondary role in amplifying an ongoing autoimmune response

questions.correct_answer: C. Transplacental passage of Tg or TPO antibodies induce neonatal hypothyroidism
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transplacental passage of Tg or TPO antibodies induce neonatal hypothyroidism Transplacental passage of Tg or TPO antibodies does not affect the fetal thyroid, which suggests that T cell-mediated injury is required to initiate autoimmune damage to the thyroid. Transplacental passage of TSH-R-blocking antibodies may induce transient neonatal hypothyroidism.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: TPO antibodies fix complement, and complement membrane-attack complexes are present in the thyroid in autoimmune hypothyroidism. Options: B, D: Antibodies to TPO and thyroglobulin (Tg) are clinically useful markers of thyroid autoimmunity, but any pathogenic effect is restricted to a secondary role in amplifying an ongoing autoimmune response.

Extraedge:

Thyroglobulin (TG): an important marker for follow-up in patients who have undergone thyroidectomy (if TG ↑→ Recurrence) Pendred syndrome: Hypothyroidism + Deafness Dyshormonogenesis: TPO defect

questions.text: A patient with hypothyroidism is being evaluated for antibodies against the TSH-R. All of the following is true about it EXCEPT?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Antibodies against the TSH-R stimulate the receptor

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: C. Antibodies against the TSH-R stimulate the receptor
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antibodies against the TSH-R stimulate the receptor Antibodies against the TSH-R, which, in contrast to thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI), do not stimulate the receptor but prevent the binding of TSH.
